facts.text: Leave granted by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: ALTAMAS KABIR,J. Leave granted. The question whether a First Information Report

facts.text: FIR No.50 of 1997 dated 31st January 1997 lodged at P.S. Vivek Vihar East Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: quash the criminal proceedings pending before the learned Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Karkardooma Court, Delhi, in FIR No.50 of 1997 dated 31st January, 1997 P.S. Vivek Vihar  East Delhi .

facts.text: Complainant Sanjay Pal resides at House No. A-25, Jhilmil Colony, Vivek Vihar, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Statement of Sanjay Pal S o Mahendra singh Pal R o House No. A-25, Jhilmil Colony, Vivek Vihar, Delhi, stated that I reside at the above mentioned address with my family.

facts.text: Sanjay Pal financed Maruti Van DL-1CB-4065 from Manoj Kumar Sharma of Vijay Lakshmi Finance Investment Company for Rs. 30,000 about two years before FIR.

anchor.surface_text: I got financed a Maruti Van bearing No. DL- 1CB-4065 from Shri Manoj Kumar Sharma - Vijay Lakshmi Finance Investment Company before two years back for a companysideration amount of Rs. 30,000/-

facts.text: Sanjay Pal paid Rs. 3954 as first installment.

anchor.surface_text: and I paid Rs. 3954/- as first installment. After that Shri Man Mohan Sharma R o D-131, Jhilmil Colony, came and told me that your finance is fabricated one,

facts.text: Man Mohan Sharma of D-131, Jhilmil Colony informed finance was fabricated and transferred to Real Auto Deals run by his brother-in-law.

anchor.surface_text: After that Shri Man Mohan Sharma R o D-131, Jhilmil Colony, came and told me that your finance is fabricated one, that is why your vehicle has number been financed by me from Real Auto Deals which is run by my brother-in-law.

facts.text: Man Mohan Sharma took old R.C. and gave new R.C. for Real Auto Deals.

anchor.surface_text: I have received the payment given by you and your file. He asked me to give return the first R.C. He gave me the new R.C I returned him the old R.C.

facts.text: Man Mohan Sharma received monthly installments in cash from Sanjay Pal without proper receipts or letterhead of Real Auto Deals.

anchor.surface_text: Man Mohan Sharma used to receive the installments in cash every month from me. The receipts issued to me put up with neither rubber stamp number used the letter head of Real Auto Deals.

facts.text: Cheques from Sanjay Pal encashed by Man Mohan Sharma in different names instead of Real Auto Deals account.

anchor.surface_text: The cheques received from me, encashed him in different-different names instead depositing in the account of Real Auto Deals.

facts.text: Sanjay Pal stopped payment of cheques after notice to pay in name of Real Auto Deals.

anchor.surface_text: When it has companye to my numberice that he is playing fraud with me, then visited the bank and got stopped the payment of the cheques. He came to me when the cheque was dishonoured and asked me why you stop the payment.

facts.text: On 27.12.1995 at about 10 O'clock, Man Mohan Sharma with unknown person took Maruti Van without consent using police stamped paper.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on 27.12.1995 at about 10 Oclock he came to me in Jhilmil along with an unknown person, I can recognize him if he companyes to me, took my said Maruti Van with his help without my companysent by showing me a paper duly stamped by the police.

facts.text: Vijay Lakshmi Finance, Real Auto Deals and Man Mohan Sharma sold the vehicle using forged signatures.

anchor.surface_text: Vijay Lakshmi Finance, Real Auto Deals and Man Mohan Sharma, have sold my vehicle to some other place by making my forged signatures and by playing fraud with me, in companynivance of each other.

facts.text: FIR under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether a First Information Report under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed either under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

facts.text: Accused and complainant compromised and settled the matter.

anchor.surface_text: when the accused and the companyplainant have companypromised and settled the matter between themselves, is the question which arises for decision in this appeal.

facts.text: Charges framed against appellant Manoj Sharma and co-accused Man Mohan Sharma based on FIR.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the above FIR charges were framed against the appellant and companyaccused Man Mohan Sharma.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in High Court to quash FIR on ground of compromise.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a writ petition before the High Court for quashing the FIR on the ground that the matter had been companypromised between the companyplainant and the accused.

facts.text: Complainant filed affidavit withdrawing allegations due to settlement; Rs.45,000 to Manoj Sharma and Rs.45,000 to Man Mohan Sharma.

anchor.surface_text: In that writ petition an affidavit was filed by the companyplainant stating that in view of the settlement between the parties he is withdrawing the allegations against both the writ petitioners and he is also withdrawing the FIR. As per the amicable settlement a sum of Rs. 45,000/- would be paid to the appellant Manoj Sharma and a further sum of Rs. 45,000/- would be paid to the companyaccused Man Mohan Sharma.

facts.text: Delhi High Court rejected writ petition on 17.8.2007.

anchor.surface_text: However, the Delhi High Court by the impugned judgment dated 17.8.2007 rejected the writ petition and hence this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court order, quashes criminal proceedings in FIR No.50/1997 before Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Karkardooma Court, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court and quash the criminal proceedings pending before the learned Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Karkardooma Court, Delhi, in FIR No.50 of 1997 dated 31st January, 1997 P.S. Vivek Vihar  East Delhi .

facts.text: Case is Criminal Appeal No. OF 2008 from Special Leave Petition Criminal No. 5265 of 2007, Manoj Sharma vs State Others.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPEAL NO.OF 2008 Special Leave Petition Criminal No. 5265 of 2007 Manoj Sharma Appellant -versus State Others Respondents

facts.text: Judgment dated October 16, 2008.

issues.text: whether a First Information Report under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed either under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure or under Article 226 of the Constitution, when the accused and the complainant have compromised and settled the matter between themselves

anchor.surface_text: The question whether a First Information Report under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed either under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure or under Article 226 of the Constitution, when the accused and the complainant have

issues.text: whether an FIR under Section 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed under Section 482 Cr.P.C. or Article 226 of the Constitution when the accused and the complainant have compromised and settled the matter between themselves

anchor.surface_text: The question involved in this case is whether an FIR under Section 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed under Section 482 Cr.P.C. or Article 226 of the Constitution when the accused and the complainant have compromised and settled the matte

issues.text: whether the decision rendered in B.S. Joshis case required a second look

anchor.surface_text: the decision rendered in B.S. Joshis case required a second look. Relying on the decision of this Court in Inspector of Police, CBI vs. Rajagopal, 2002  9  SCC 533, K.G. Prem Shankar vs. Inspector of Police and Anr. JT 2002  7  SC 30 and also Textile Labour Association and Anr. Vs. Official Liquidator and Anr. JT 2004  suppl.1  SC 1, Mr. Singh submitted that in B.S. Joshis case there was a departure from the view taken in the first of the two aforesaid cases.

issues.text: whether the High Court had exercised its jurisdiction under Section 482 Cr.P.C. legally and correctly

anchor.surface_text: In any event, in this case, we are only required to consider whether the High Court had exercised its jurisdiction under Section 482 Cr.P.C. legally and correctly. In view of the nature of the offences set out in the complaint, the High Court did not consider it an appropriate case for exercising its jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution for quashing the same.

issues.text: whether the High Courts refusal to exercise its jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution for quashing the criminal proceedings can be supported

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Courts refusal to exercise its jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution for quashing the criminal proceedings cannot be supported. The First Information Report, which had been lodged by the complainant indicates a dispute between the complainant and the accused which is of a private nature.

issues.text: Whether power under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 is limited or circumscribed by Section 320 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: the power of the High Court under Section 482 of the Code to quash Criminal proceedings or FIR or complaint were not circumscribed by Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. While the appellant herein strongly relied on the decision in B.S. Joshis case.

issues.text: whether non-compoundable offences can be quashed under Section 482 Cr.P.C. or Article 226 on the basis of compromise between parties

anchor.surface_text: However, Section 320 (9) Cr.P.C. expressly states that no offence shall be compounded except as provided by that Section. ... Section 482 Cr.P.C. which reads Saving of inherent power of High Court. - Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent powers of the High Court

issues.text: whether a case under Section 302 IPC or other serious offences like those under Sections 395, 307 or 304B can be quashed under Section 482 Cr.P.C. or Article 226 on basis of compromise

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that a case under Section 302 IPC or other serious offences like those under Sections 395, 307 or 304B cannot be compounded and hence proceedings in those provisions cannot be quashed by the High Court in exercise of its power under Section 482 Cr.P.C.

arguments.claim: Criminal proceedings or FIR under non-compoundable offences can be quashed under Section 482 CrPC if parties have compromised.

anchor.surface_text: wherein also the question arose as to whether criminal proceedings or a First Information Report or complaint filed under Section 498-A and 406 IPC by the wife could be quashed under Section 482 CrPC on account of the fact that the offences complained of were not compoundable under Section 320 of the Code.

arguments.claim: Power under Section 482 CrPC to quash is not circumscribed by Section 320 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: In B.S. Joshis case, this Court drew a distinction between compounding an offence as permitted under Section 320 CrPC and quashing of the complaint or criminal proceedings under Section 482 CrPC as also Article 226 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Appellant relies on B.S. Joshi to quash FIR due to compromise.

anchor.surface_text: While the appellant herein strongly relied on the decision in B.S. Joshis case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: .S. Joshis case required a second look. Relying on the decision of this Court in Inspector of Police, CBI vs. Rajagopal, 2002  9  SCC 533, K.G. Prem S

arguments.court_reasoning: Court follows B.S. Joshi and applies it to facts.

arguments.claim: B.S. Joshi requires second look as it departs from prior precedents; specific compounding provisions limit quashing.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. B.B. Singh, learned counsel appearing for the respondent-State urged that having regard to the specific provision in the Code regarding compounding of offences... required a second look. Relying on...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to companysider whether the High Court had exercised its jurisdiction under Section 482 Cr.P.C. legally and companyrectly. In view of the nature of t

arguments.court_reasoning: Court not inclined to reconsider B.S. Joshi; power under S.482 not limited by S.320.

arguments.claim: B.S. Joshi does not require reconsideration; High Court power under S.482/Art 226 not limited by S.320.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully considered the submissions made on behalf of the respective parties... we are not inclined to accept Mr. Singhs contention that the decision in B.S. Joshis case requires reconsideration.

arguments.qualifiers: at least not in the facts of this case

arguments.claim: High Court did not exercise jurisdiction under S.482 correctly.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, in this case, we are only required to consider whether the High Court had exercised its jurisdiction under Section 482 Cr.P.C. legally and correctly.

arguments.claim: High Court's refusal to quash under Art 226 cannot be supported; dispute is private nature.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Courts refusal to exercise its jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution for quashing the criminal proceedings cannot be supported. The First Information Report... indicates a dispute... of a private nature.

arguments.claim: Continuing proceedings is futile due to compromise; quash FIR.

anchor.surface_text: In the facts of this case we are of the view that continuing with the criminal proceedings would be an exercise in futility.

arguments.claim: FIR under 420/468/471/34/120B can be quashed u/s 482 CrPC or Art 226 on compromise.

anchor.surface_text: The question involved in this case is whether an FIR under Section 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed under Section 482 Cr.P.C. or Article 226... when the accused and the complainant have compromised.

arguments.claim: Offences in FIR are non-compoundable except 420; cannot quash per S.320(9).

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of Section 320 shows that offences under Section 468, 471, 34 and 120-B IPC... cannot even be compounded with the permission of the Court... Section 320(9) Cr.P.C. expressly states that no offence shall be compounded except as provided by this Section.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sion in Madhu Limaye vs. State of Maharashtra 1977  4  SCC 551 in which it was held  vide para 8  that the power under Section 482 should number be ex

arguments.court_reasoning: Acknowledges but S.482 overrides in rare cases.

arguments.claim: Courts cannot quash non-compoundable offences on compromise; violates statute.

anchor.surface_text: Shri B.B. Singh... submitted that the High Court or even this Court would not be justified in giving directions to quash a criminal proceeding... when the offence has been expressly made non-compoundable by Section 320 Cr.P.C.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sion in Madhu Limaye vs. State of Maharashtra 1977  4  SCC 551 in which it was held  vide para 8  that the power under Section 482 should number be ex

arguments.court_reasoning: S.482 non-obstante clause allows in rare cases.

arguments.claim: Ordinarily agree with respondent on judicial restraint and separation of powers; cannot override S.320.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily we would have agreed with Mr. B.B. Singh. The doctrine of judicial restraint... restricts the power of the Court... there is a broad separation of powers... would not ordinarily be justified.

arguments.claim: S.320 cannot be read in isolation; must read with S.482 which has non-obstante clause overriding it.

anchor.surface_text: However, it has to be pointed out that Section 320 Cr.P.C. cannot be read in isolation. It has to be read along with... Section 482 Cr.P.C.... Nothing in this Code... is a non obstante clause.

arguments.claim: Prior judgments barring S.482 override not Euclid's formula; departure possible in rare cases.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in certain decisions... power under Section 482 Cr.P.C. cannot be exercised to do something which is expressly barred... However... judgments cannot be read mechanically and like a Euclids theorem.

arguments.claim: Serious offences like 302, 395, 307, 304B cannot be quashed on compromise.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that a case under Section 302 IPC or other serious offences like those under Sections 395, 307 or 304B cannot be compounded and hence proceedings... cannot be quashed.

arguments.claim: This case akin to civil nature; quashable on settlement even if non-compoundable.

anchor.surface_text: However, in some other cases, like those akin to a civil nature the proceedings can be quashed... even though the provisions are non compoundable.

holdings.text: A First Information Report under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 when accused and complainant have compromised and settled.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether a First Information Report under Sections 420/468/471/34/120-B IPC can be quashed either under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure or under Article 226 of the Constitution, when the accused and the complainant have

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms B.S. Joshi; inherent power under S.482 not limited by S.320 for non-compoundable offences in private disputes settled amicably to secure ends of justice.

holdings.text: Decision in B.S. Joshi's case does not require reconsideration; power under S.482/Art 226 to quash non-compoundable offences not circumscribed by S.320 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: the decision rendered in B.S. Joshis case required a second look. Relying on the decision of this Court in Inspector of Police, CBI vs. Rajagopal, 2002  9  SCC 533, K.G. Prem Shankar vs. Inspector of Police and Anr. JT 2002  7  SC 30 and also Textile Labour Association and Anr. Vs. Official Liquidator and Anr. JT 2004  suppl.1  SC 1, Mr. Singh submitted that in B.S. Joshis case there was a departure from the view taken in the first of the two aforesaid cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects respondent's argument distinguishing prior precedents; follows B.S. Joshi distinguishing compounding from quashing.

holdings.text: High Court failed to exercise jurisdiction under S.482 CrPC legally and correctly; refusal under Art 226 unsupported as dispute is private nature.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, in this case, we are only required to consider whether the High Court had exercised its jurisdiction under Section 482 Cr.P.C. legally and correctly. In view of the nature of the offences set out in the complaint, the High Court did not consider it an appropriate case for exercising its jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution for quashing the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: FIR indicates private dispute; complainant withdrew; pragmatic exercise required to prevent abuse.

holdings.text: Criminal proceedings in FIR No.50/1997 quashed as continuing would be futile post-settlement.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court and quash the criminal proceedings pending before the learned Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Karkardooma Court, Delhi, in FIR No.50 of 1997 dated 31st January, 1997 P.S. Vivek Vihar  East Delhi .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies S.482 to facts: private financial dispute settled with payments, no public interest.

holdings.text: Section 482 CrPC has non-obstante overriding effect over S.320(9); allows quashing non-compoundable offences in rare cases unlike serious offences e.g. 302/395/307/304B IPC.

anchor.surface_text: However, Section 320 (9) Cr.P.C. expressly states that no offence shall be compounded except as provided by that Section. ... There can be no doubt that a case under Section 302 IPC or other serious offences like those under Sections 395, 307 or 304B cannot be compounded

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction; S.482 saves inherent powers to secure justice despite S.320 bar; limits to non-serious private cases.

holdings.text: Cases under S.302/395/307/304B IPC cannot be quashed under S.482/Art226 even on compromise.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that a case under Section 302 IPC or other serious offences like those under Sections 395, 307 or 304B cannot be compounded and hence proceedings in those provisions cannot be quashed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Serious offences affect society; non-compoundable and non-quashable on settlement.

holdings.text: Guidelines needed by larger Bench for quashing non-compoundable cases on compromise to avoid judicial anarchy.

anchor.surface_text: Where a line is to be drawn will have to be decided in some later decisions of this Court, preferably by a larger bench  so as to make it more authoritative . Some guidelines will have to be evolved in this connection

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevents conflicting decisions; discretion must be guided objectively.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, in this case, we are only required to consider whether the High Court had exercised its jurisdiction under Section 482 Cr.P.C. legally and correctly. In view of the nature of the offences set out in the complaint, the High Court did not consider it an appropriate case for exercising its jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution for quashing the same.

We, accordingly, allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court and quash the criminal proceedings pending before the learned Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Karkardooma Court, Delhi, in FIR No.50 of 1997 dated 31st January, 1997 P.S. Vivek Vihar  E
